Description: Egyptian terracotta naked female figure plaque, concealing breasts with left arm. Bottom and right side missing. Crudely made with prominent eyes, nose and lips. Mould-made and solid with crude back. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Locally made Nile Delta plaque figure of a naked woman. Unusual style for Egypt, with closest parallels from Cypus dating to the early Cypro-Archaic period and the early 6th century BC (Karageorghis 1999, pl.19.5,8 nos II(iii)12-13 and VI(ii)8-11). Karageorghis, J. 1999. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus.V. The Cypro-Archaic Period small female figurines. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.033) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 82, nos 51-55) (?)
